message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lymphatic vessels of the foot drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The regional lymph nodes draining the foot drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the wound (plantar surface of the foot) suggests that the afferent lymphatic vessels from the site of the lesion will drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lymphatic vessels from the foot typically drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making option (B) the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lymphatic vessels from the plantar surface of the foot drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. This drainage pattern is based on the lymphatic anatomy of the lower extremity.

We refer to anatomical textbooks for help. The lymphatic vessels from the plantar surface of the foot drain into the superficial inguinal nodes, making it the correct answer. The deep inguinal nodes drain the external genitalia and anal canal, external iliac nodes drain the lower limb, pelvis, and perineum, and anterior tibial nodes drain the anterior portion of the lower leg.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lymphatic vessels from the foot drain to the superficial inguinal nodes. Deep inguinal nodes are located deep in the inguinal canal and receive drainage from the superficial inguinal nodes. External iliac nodes are located more proximally in the abdomen and receive drainage from the inguinal nodes. Anterior tibial nodes are not located in the inguinal region and do not receive drainage from the foot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The afferent lymphatic vessels from the site of the lesion would drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, which are located in the groin area. The deep inguinal lymph nodes are located deeper in the groin and drain the lower limb's deeper structures. The external iliac lymph nodes drain the lower limb proximal to the inguinal ligament, and the anterior tibial lymph nodes receive lymphatic drainage from the lower leg and medial foot.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The area surrounding the foot puncture wound drains into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lymphatic drainage of the foot is divided into two groups: the superficial group, which drains into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, and the deep group, which drains into the external iliac lymph nodes. Therefore, the answer is (B) superficial inguinal lymph nodes.
